Award.AwardTitle: TUES:Type1:Collaborative: An Integrative Hands-on Approach to Security Education for Undergraduate Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Security of information, software, and hardware has emerged as a paramount concern. Existing undergraduate curricula often do not provide students with adequate insight into the full spectrum of security threats and respective protection approaches. To fill this gap in the curriculum, this project is developing an interdisciplinary undergraduate course incorporating hands-on learning of computer security. The course provides a comprehensive system-level view of computer security to students, so they can become more aware of diverse security issues and countermeasures as future developers and users of computer systems. A distinctive aspect of the project is the inclusion of a set of well-crafted experiments that would allow students to hack into software and hardware in many creative ways. These experiments can be highly effective in demonstrating the complex nature of system security and creating an understanding of the defense mechanisms. The exposure to security issues early in their career can provide undergraduate students with a competitive edge in the market place and stimulate their interests in security research. The course modules can also benefit graduate students pursuing research in the area of computer security, as well as the K-12 students attending summer camps each year. The project provides a unique opportunity for exposing minority and female students in Cleveland State University to the critical issues of security and attracting them to higher education and research. The project uses the trust-hub web portal for disseminating the course modules to other academic institutions in a timely manner.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electronic system security has emerged as a serious concern in many spheres of our lives, given how pervasive the use of electronic system has become. These spheres may range from mobile consumer electronics, such as cell phones and tablets, to electronics used in national infrastructures and defense systems. As connectivity and ease of access through wireless connections increase, the vulnerability of these systems grows alarmingly fast. The security issues of electronic systems are diverse in nature, and they span across multiple levels and components, including information, hardware and software. There is a critical need to educate and train the future engineers and researchers with all levels of computer system security, their interplay, and the tools to provide comprehensive protection against the diverse forms of security attacks posed by the intelligent adversary.

The course modules, developed through the use of the NSF grant, provide a holistic view of security through hands-on experiments by combining network, data, software, and hardware security aspects. A major problem in computer security is that we often work to solve attacks that have happened, while paying less attention in anticipating attacks that are likely to come. Thus, encouraging students not only to learn and design solutions against known attacks, but also to come up with novel ideas of security attacks and defenses against them represents very exciting way to learn and discover security issues at all levels of cyber systems. Figure 1 shows the full spectrum of security issues in modern computer systems.

The specific focus of the hands-on course modules were (1) Introduction to hardware, software, and information security; (2) Cryptography and cryptographic protocols; (3) Hardware Trojan horses; (4) Side-channel attacks; (5) Bus Snooping attacks; (6) Power Analysis attacks; (7) Hardware IP protection; (8) Security in embedded systems; and (9) Trustworthy computing. In the beginning of the semester, students formed groups and performed experiments that dealt with common threats such as buffer overflow attacks, hardware Trojan attacks, side channel attacks, and bus snooping attacks. Then, they completed modules on several mitigation techniques, including data encryption, bus encryption, hardware obfuscation, and physically unclonable functions (PUFs). Each module was built around attempting to either hack a hardware module using an Altera board or protect it from hacking. The final project included a presentation session by each group to demonstrate a module developed by them on either hacking or protecting hardware or software.

Through the NSF grant, this course has been developed, successfully offered every year starting from 2014, and eventually incorporated in the permanent curriculum at CSU. This course has also become a regular elective course at Case Western Reserve University as well as at University of Florida, offered by our co-PI, Dr. Swarup Bhunia. Over the years, we have observed the course becoming less popular among the CIS students, as opposed to CE students. In order to improve the enrollment of CS students, student feedback was taken into account, and we developed supplementary materials on hardware, enhanced the existing hardware security experiments, and posted on the portal and CSU website. In addition, we adapted some of the course modules for high school students and presented to the local K-12 students. The K-12 students were particularly excited and motivated to further explore the subject matter.

Security education is a requirement for the community, not just graduate and undergraduate students. The security of pervasively-used highly-connected computer systems is a complex issue, and technology alone cannot adequately address it. It is important to create wide-spread awareness of the diverse security issues and countermeasures. Hence, exposing students to a holistic view of computer security through our security course can greatly contribute to creating future system developers and users who are well-aware of the security issues and can effectively defend against them. The hands-on approach of security training can motivate students to discover new flaws and weaknesses that have not been anticipated by system manufacturers and develop new countermeasures. Graduate students, undergraduate students, and local K-12 students alike have benefited from the course modules.
